children.subject: I had no idea, thank you! My question is, if they do hire undergrads for upper div courses, why only offer 1-2 summer upper div courses? I understand you can't always recruit faculty to teach, but I'm sure you can find a smart and qualified undergrad, and if not, a grad student.
If you have concrete people you think could teach, feel free to encourage them to apply and/or approach Prof Garcia or Rao to encourage them to attempt to recruit them.

I think the biggest reason that's typically been cited is the fact that people who have progressed along that far (taken several upper divs, TA'd a couple times for it such that they're qualified to teach it) are usually giving up a significant opportunity cost to teach (interning -- and if you think about it, if they're good enough to be teaching 188, they probably are also ideal candidates for that well paid and prestigious job over at Google or Facebook) so I think paying them requisitely (15k for a summer? free tuition for life?) is the real bottleneck.
Qualified undergraduates are sometimes hired as summer instructors for upper-div classes. I believe that one of the instructors for CS188 last summer was an undergrad.

history.content: Feel free to visit Prof Garcia or Rao who recruit summer instructors and have a better sense of what the rules and limitations are.

Just wondering, why are there only undergrad instructors for lower division CS courses over the summer? I believe the main reason more CS upper div's aren't offered over the summer is because the lack of qualified instructors. This problem, however, has been circumvented by hiring undergraduate instructors over the summer. Why not also do the same for upper division courses? It would solve a major problem and allow students to take a lot more cs courses over the summer.

Thank you!
history.subject: Undergrad instructors over the summer?

history.content:
